awd_titl_txt: EAGER: The Geoscience behind Resilient Infrastructure Careers: Unlocking the Intrinsic Value of Diverse Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal outlines the Emerging Geoscience Scholars (EGS) model, a novel approach towards nurturing talent and welcoming identity. The PIs propose to pilot new approaches to the engagement of professional societies with people in the cities that host their annual meetings. The PIs propose to start modestly with 20-30 scholars from historically underrepresented communities, disconnected youth, veterans, and transitional (unemployed or underemployed) people per year investigating careers and sharing their findings as emerging professionals at a major geoscience conference, the Fall Meeting of the American Geophysical Union (AGU). By sharing their work in a professional science meeting and putting the weight of a major scientific society and large academic institution behind those investigations, ideas can grow into a practice that can ultimately transform the geoscience infrastructure and workforce as well as other scientific and professional associations. With the emphasis that the Biden Administration has put on infrastructure and conservation, partnering with AGU, and the many professions it covers, is an ideal starting point for this experimental program.

This program aims to increase the capacity for a resilient and sustainable built infrastructure and advance climate justice, by ensuring that the geoscience and the wider infrastructure workforce of the future adopts values and methods that center on and embrace the core values of equity, justice, and inclusiveness - from diversity comes strength. A sustainable future workforce for the geosciences must be composed of, and ultimately led by, people of color, Native Americans, and immigrants. It must start now with this rising generation. This proposed learning/training ecosystem is designed to be an open-source model or template that can be adopted by other professional associations and partnering educational institutions nationwide; it thus contributes to the common educational and research infrastructure for the development of a diverse and globally competitive US workforce. By addressing issues important to urban coastal communities under pressures from climate change, the effort has the potential to improve the wellbeing of people in society. By educating and engaging youth and lifelong learners in local scientific and social issues, it helps develop a more involved and informed public as well as broadening racial and ethnic diversity in the geosciences

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to develop a novel on-ramp to geoscience careers for a broad and inclusive group of learners through the formation of a unique partnership between the Arizona State University (ASU), the American Geophysical Union (AGU), local communities in cities hosting the AGU annual meetings, industry partners, and local government.  The partnership developed and deployed an equity-centered geoscience learning ecosystem (GLE) that defined roles for educators, mentors, geoscience experts, private industry employers, local government, workforce leaders, emerging professionals, nonprofit partners, and scholars in the creation of a symbiotic learning ecosystem.  This partnership sought to increase the visibility of often overlooked geoscience careers and the wider range of careers in sustainable environmental infrastructure for emergent scholars across STEM and STEM-adjacent disciplines. Another goal of this project was the development of a transferable model of curriculum and experiential activities for other professional associations, community colleges and universities, and governments to adopt and support to engage transitional age youth and lifelong learners to build the pipeline of future geoscience and environmental professionals. 

The program that was implemented was called the Future Leaders and Geoscience High-Road Internship Program (FLAGSHIP) and we supported two nationwide cohorts of emergent scholars who will enter the workforce over the next five years equipped with an enhanced understanding of infrastructure-related career opportunities and how to incorporate community concerns, ideals of environmental justice, and sustainability principles.

Key Results
  • Creation of a transferable model for partnering with professional societies, academic institutions, communities, and industry for interdisciplinary workforce development both inside and outside academia 
  • Development of an academically rigorous curriculum rooted in practical career pathways explorations, field and conference experience
  • Supported 42 emergent scholars in the FLAGSHIP Program.  Over 80% were 1st-generation college students and this was their first research experience.  This was an intentional element of the program - to expand opportunities to students often let behind because of class or preparation.
  • Provided over 3500 hours of experiential training in collaboration with workforce professionals
  • 100% of the participants delivered conference presentations at a national meeting
  • 75% of the participants have entered the STEM workforce
  • Assisted the scholars in application processes for awards and internships that led to 50% of the total number of students winning new merit-based financial awards
  • Increased the professional networks of all cohort members.  This was measured by the number of new LinkedIn connections with professionals contacted through the FLAGSHIP experience.  Participants averaged 25 new professional connections over the course of the program.
  • Enable the formal adoption of the FLAGSHIP model in collaboration with Project Cities to offer two new courses collaborating with two Phoenix West Valley municipalities (anticipated to be Goodyear and Buckeye in Fall '25)
